p: Nearly all countries in sub-Saharan Africa have now adopted national polices to offer ART to all PLWHIV regardless of CD4 cell count or clinical stage (‘Treat All’), in order to meet the UNAIDS 90-90-90 targets. In 2011, Malawi was one of the first countries to implement such a strategy for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission, recommending ART for pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV, regardless of CD4 cell count or WHO clinical stage (‘Option B+’). An IeDEA analysis of the Malawian experience showed that poor retention in care was a problem in many facilities, with early loss to follow-up particularly high in facilities with a high patient volume and in patients who start ART during pregnancy on the day of HIV diagnosis. 35 More recently, IeDEA investigators used regression discontinuity analysis to examine changes in rapid HIV treatment initiation after national ‘Treat All’ policy adoption in six countries (Burundi, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Uganda and Zambia). 60 They showed a strong and sustained effect of the adoption of ‘Treat All’ policies on ART initiation within 30 days of enrollment in HIV care in all six countries. 60
